DataElement.preferredName: Derived Lung Carcinoma Disease Screening Less Prior Cancer Diagnosis Date Calculated Year Value
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Time interval from the date of lung cancer screening to the date of prior cancer diagnosis, represented as a calculated number of years.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Lung Carcinoma Disease Screening Subtraction Prior Cancer Diagnosis Time Duration
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma originating in the lung. Lung carcinomas usually arise from the epithelium that lines the bronchial tree (bronchogenic carcinomas), and are classified as small cell or non-small cell carcinomas. Non-small cell lung carcinomas are usually adenocarcinomas, squamous cell carcinomas, or large cell carcinomas. Metastatic carcinomas to the lung are also common, and can be difficult to distinguish from primary tumors._The use of any device, marker, or other means for the purpose of detecting the presence of disease, usually in asymptomatic individuals._The act of removing a part from the whole._Earlier in time or order._A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas._The investigation, analysis and recognition of the presence and nature of disease, condition, or injury from expressed signs and symptoms; also, the scientific determination of any kind; the concise results of such an investigation.:The continuum of experience in which events pass from the future through the present to the past._The period of time during which something continues.

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma originating in the lung. Lung carcinomas usually arise from the epithelium that lines the bronchial tree (bronchogenic carcinomas), and are classified as small cell or non-small cell carcinomas. Non-small cell lung carcinomas are usually adenocarcinomas, squamous cell carcinomas, or large cell carcinomas. Metastatic carcinomas to the lung are also common, and can be difficult to distinguish from primary tumors.
The use of any device, marker, or other means for the purpose of detecting the presence of disease, usually in asymptomatic individuals.
The act of removing a part from the whole.

A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.

The investigation, analysis and recognition of the presence and nature of disease, condition, or injury from expressed signs and symptoms; also, the scientific determination of any kind; the concise results of such an investigation.

Concepts.definition: The continuum of experience in which events pass from the future through the present to the past.
The period of time during which something continues.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period._The procedure or activity of determining something by mathematical or logical methods._A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.
